coredata.dc:title: Discovery of novel inhibitors of signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3) signaling pathway by virtual screening
coredata.prism:publicationName: European Journal of Medicinal ChemistryJournalfla0223523462301310301-310text/xml2013-04-30April 2013Copyright © 2013 Elsevier Masson SAS. All rights reserved.Elsevier Masson SAS.Zhang, MingmingZhu, WeiliangLi, Yingxia Inhibition of the signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3) signaling pathway has been considered a novel therapeutic strategy to treat human cancers that harbor aberrantly-active STAT3. In this study, nearly 204,000 compounds in Specs database were screened by virtual screening, and samples of top 100 compounds identified as candidate small-molecule inhibitors of STAT3 were evaluated by STAT3-dependent luciferase reporter assay as well as other cell-based assays. A benzothiazole core scaffold containing compound, 9, was identified as an inhibitor of IL-6/STAT3 signaling with an IC50 of 3.567 μM. It is the first time to discover benzothiazole scaffold as a potent STAT3 signaling inhibitor. We further investigated the (structure–activity relationship) SAR of the benzothiazole analogues, and discovered compound 16w as a better small-molecule inhibitor. Both compounds inhibited the phosphorylation of STAT3 and had no obvious effect on upstream JAK2 kinase. 0falsefalseSTAT3 signalingSmall-molecule inhibitorsVirtual screeningCell viabilityAntitumor activity

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Structures of 1, STX-0119, Nicloamides, T3, Cucurbitacin Q and 16w.
Structures of the discovered active compounds.

Compound 9 and 16w inhibited the phosphorylation of STAT3. (A) Curcumin led to does-dependent inhibition of STAT3 phosphorylation. (B) Compounds 9 and 16w inhibited Tyr705 phosphorylation at 50 μM. (C) Compounds 9 and 16w had no obvious effect on JAK2 and p-JAK2. HepG2 cells were pretreated with compounds for 6 h before stimulation by IL-6 (10 ng/mL) for 15 min. Whole cell lysates were processed for Western blot analysis and probed with the indicated antibodies. GAPDH served as a loading control.

Docking mode of compound 9 with STAT3 generated by GLIDE. Visible by PyMol. Carbon atoms of compound 9 are colored cyan, and those of phosphotyrosine peptide (APpYLKTKF) are colored yellow. Hydrogen bonding to Gln644, Glu638, and Gln635 are shown by red dashed lines. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

Synthesis of derivatives 16a–y. Reagents and conditions: (a) 2-chloroacetyl chloride, Et3N, CH2Cl2, 0 °C to RT, 6 h, yield 70–82%; (b) 6-amino-2-mercaptobenzothiazole, K2CO3, acetone, reflux, 4 h, yield 90–95%; (c) benzoyl chloride/4-methoxybenzoyl chloride/2-methoxybenzoyl chloride/4-nitrobenzoyl chloride/acetyl chloride/2-chloroacetyl chloride/isobutyrl chloride/cyclopropanecarbonyl chloride/propionyl chloride/15a–g, K2CO3, CH2Cl2, RT, 4–12 h, yield 60–80%.
Inhibitory potency of the tested molecules.

head.ce:title: Discovery of novel inhibitors of signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3) signaling pathway by virtual screening

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: School of Pharmacy, Fudan University, 826 Zhangheng Road, Shanghai 201203, China

ce:affiliation.ce:label: b
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Shanghai Institute of Material Medica, Chinese Academy of Science, 555 Zuchongzhi Road, Shanghai 201203, China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Inhibition of the signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3) signaling pathway has been considered a novel therapeutic strategy to treat human cancers that harbor aberrantly-active STAT3. In this study, nearly 204,000 compounds in Specs database were screened by virtual screening, and samples of top 100 compounds identified as candidate small-molecule inhibitors of STAT3 were evaluated by STAT3-dependent luciferase reporter assay as well as other cell-based assays. A benzothiazole core scaffold containing compound, 9, was identified as an inhibitor of IL-6/STAT3 signaling with an IC50 of 3.567 μM. It is the first time to discover benzothiazole scaffold as a potent STAT3 signaling inhibitor. We further investigated the (structure–activity relationship) SAR of the benzothiazole analogues, and discovered compound 16w as a better small-molecule inhibitor. Both compounds inhibited the phosphorylation of STAT3 and had no obvious effect on upstream JAK2 kinase.
Docking mode of compound 9 with STAT3 generated by GLIDE. Compound 9 formed three hydrogen bonds with Gln644, Glu638, and Gln635.

► Novel enzothiazole scaffold against STAT3 signaling by virtual screening. ► Showed potent activity in STAT3-dependent luciferase reporter assay. ► Showed potent activity in cell line harboring constitutively active STAT3. ► Inhibited (Tyr705) phosphorylation of STAT3. ► Had no obvious effect on upstream tyrosine kinases.

ce:section.ce:para: The signal transducer and activator of transcription (STATs) family proteins are a class of transcription factors that modulate cellular responses, including cell proliferation and differentiation, inflammation and immune responses [1,2]. STATs signaling can be activated by upstream cytokines, growth factors, and other polypeptide ligands [2]. At least seven members (STAT1 – 4, STAT5a, STAT5b and STAT6) have been identified in mammalian cells. Among these members, STAT3 has been attached great importance and is the most studied member because of its role in malignant tumorigenesis and transformation. STAT3 is frequently overexpressed or persistently activated in most tumors, including ovarian, cervical, breast, head and neck squamous cell carcinoma, prostate, and leukemias [3]. STAT3-mediated tumorigenesis may be attributed to up-regulation of genes encoding antiapoptotic and proliferation-associated proteins (like Bcl-2, Bcl-xL, Mcl-1, Cyclin D1, and c-Myc), inducer of tumor angiogenesis (like VEGF and FGF), and promoter of tumor cell migration and invasion (like MMP-1, -2, -9, and -10) [4]. In addition, studies also indicated that activated STAT3 suppressed tumor-immune surveillance [5]. During activation, tyrosine residue 705 (Tyr705) in the STAT3 SH2 domain is phosphorylated, consequently leading STAT3 monomers to dimerize through a reciprocal pTyr-SH2 domain interaction, translocate into the nucleus, recognize STAT3-specific DNA binding elements, and mediate target gene transcription [1,2]. Given its importance to tumorigenesis, STAT3 represents an attractive target for discovery of new anticancer drug and is currently under intense investigation.

Heretofore, several classes of STAT3 inhibitors have been identified using multiple approaches such as peptide-based rational design, virtual screening of large chemical libraries, high throughput screening, repositioning using multiple ligand simultaneous docking (MLSD), and fragment-based drug design. Some of them exhibited high potency against STAT3 signaling, including peptidomimetics (1), STX-0119 (2), Niclosamide (3), T3 (4), and the natural product Cucurbitacin Q (5) (Fig. 1 ) [6–10]. The peptide and peptidomimetic inhibitory approaches face several challenges in terms of the low cell permeability, stability, and the consequential low biological activities, whereas non-peptidic small-molecules represent a rather more attractive approach to inhibit aberrant STAT3 activity in cancer cells. Recently, a few STAT3-specific small-molecule inhibitors, including OPB-31121 and OPB-51602 have entered into clinical trials [11]. The future of research in STAT3 inhibition should focus on seeking potent small-molecule inhibitors with novel scaffold. In this study, we screened nearly 204,000 compounds by virtual database screening, and reported the identification of 6-aminobenzo[d]thiazole-2-thiol analogues as novel potent small-molecule inhibitors of the STAT3 signaling pathway for the first time.

Our structure-based virtual screening employed molecular docking program DOCK (Version 4.0) and GLIDE (http://www.schrödinger.com) to search for novel STAT3 inhibitors [12–14]. The X-ray crystal structure of the STAT3β homodimer bound to DNA solved at 2.25-Å resolution was retrieved from Protein Data Bank (PDB code: 1BG1) for docking simulation. Double-stranded DNA, all crystallographic water, and PO4 3− buffer molecules were removed. The native pTyr (pY) peptide, APpYLKTKF was extracted from the crystal structure of one of the monomers as a ligand. The residues within a radius of 5-Å around the ligand were used to construct the grids for docking screening. First, DOCK4.0 was used to search the Specs chemical database (October, 2010; http://www.specs.net) for potential binders of STAT3. Subsequently, the top 10% ranked compounds with the highest score obtained by DOCK were selected for the second round docking by GLIDE SP (Standard Precision mode), then the top 500 molecules were filtered again by GLIDE XP (Extra Precision mode). Finally, according to the scores, structural diversity, and visual inspection, we manually selected and purchased 100 molecules for inhibitory activity assay.

Twenty-five benzothiazole-based inhibitors were synthesized (Table 2 ), and evaluated by STAT3-dependent luciferase reporter assay and cell viability assay (MTT) to explore the SARs. Among these compounds, the most potent compound 16w inhibited IL-6/STAT3 signaling pathway with an IC50 of 1.16 μM, 3-fold increase in potency compared with compound 9. In the cell viability assay, 16w significantly inhibited cell viability of MDA-MB-468 with an IC50 of 16.06 μM.

To further validate the inhibitory activity of these two compounds against STAT3 pathway, western blot analysis was used. Our results showed that treatment with compound 9 or 16w consistently inhibited STAT3 phosphorylation in HepG2 cell line. As shown in Fig. 3 , curcumin dose-dependently inhibited Tyr705 phosphorylation, and compounds 9 and 16w remarkably inhibited Tyr705 phosphorylation at 50 μM, whereas the total STAT3 protein level remained unchanged after 6 h incubation. In addition, the influence of compounds 9 and 16w on upstream tyrosine kinase was also determined. These two compounds had no obvious effects on the protein levels of JAK and p-JAK after 6 h treatment.

The route adapted for the synthesis of these benzothiazole-based derivatives 16a–y is outlined in Scheme 1 , using a modified literature method [15,16]. The starting compounds 12a–g were prepared from commercially available phenylamine or benzylamine derivatives, and 2-chloroacetyl chloride. In the next step, 12a–g were condensed with 6-aminobenzothiazole-2-thiol in refluxing acetone, affording the amines 13a–g. Then, target compounds 16a–y were obtained, respectively, by the reaction between 13a–g and the corresponding acyl chloride in the presence of potassium carbonate at room temperature in dichloromethane. The acyl chlorides are commercially available or prepared from corresponding benzoic acids reacted with SOCl2 (15a–g). The yield of all reactions was satisfactory. All the products were characterized by 1H NMR, 13C NMR and MS analyses.

A docking model of compound 9 bound to the STAT3–SH2 domain was generated on the basis of crystal structure of STAT3β homodimer (PDB code 1BG1) by GLIDE. As illustrated in Fig. 4 , 4-Br-Ph inserted into a small hydrophobic cleft in a manner similar to Phe710 of the phosphotyrosine peptide. The amide–NH close to R1 participated in a hydrogen bond interaction with residue Gln644. In addition, CO of the other amide close to R2 formed a hydrogen bond with the backbone amide–NH of Glu638, and the oxygen atom of the methoxyl group formed another hydrogen bond with Gln635. Interestingly, this compound acted as a partial peptidomimetic of phosphotyrosine peptide (APpYLKTKF) without the segment having polar interactions with the pTyr-binding pocket surrounded by Lys591, Arg609, and Ser611.

The inhibitory activity of the synthesized compounds 16a–y on STAT3-dependent luciferase reporter gene assay is listed in Table 2. Among the analogues, 2,6-diethylphenyl or (S)-methylbenzyl group on R1 was optimal for the inhibitory activity against STAT3 signaling (16n, 16s–x). Aromatic ring (R2) was essential, and replacement of this aromatic group with alkanes completely abolished the activity (16h–k). Regarding the substitution on R2 ring, 2-OMe-Ph (16f), 4-OMe-Ph (16s), 4-pyridyl (16n), and 3-pyridyl (16o) groups were tolerated; however, the incorporation of 2-OMe-benzyl rendered the compound inactive (16m). In addition, the presence of long-chain alkenes on the phenyl ring resulted in the improved activity of compounds (16t–z). It might be due to the hydrophobic interactions between the alkene chain and the residue Gln635, Ile634, and Gln635.

Here we reported the discovery of novel inhibitors of STAT3 signaling pathway by virtual screening. Among these compounds, 9 and 16w potently inhibited activation and transactivation of STAT3 but had no obvious effects on the closely related IFN-γ/STAT1, TNF-α/NF-КB signaling pathway, and the upstream JAK2 kinase. Furthermore, these two compounds greatly inhibited the viability of human breast cell line MDA-MB-468 harboring constitutively active STAT3. Therefore, they represented new potent lead compounds with benzothiazole scaffold for development of STAT3 pathway inhibitors as molecular-targeted anticancer drugs. The extensive studies of the mechanisms are currently undergoing and will be reported in due course.

HepG2/STAT3 cells, a gift from Prof. Xinyuan Fu (National University of Singapore, Singapore), were HepG2 cells stably transfected with a STAT3-responsive firefly luciferase reporter plasmid. All other cell lines were obtained from the American Type Culture Collection (USA).

HepG2/STAT3 cells (1.5 × 105 per well) were seeded into 24-well microplates (Corning) and allowed to grow for 48 h and then treated with test samples for 1 h followed by stimulation with 10 ng/mL interleukin (IL)-6 (BD Biosciences) for 5.5 h. Luciferase activity was determined using a Promega luciferase kit according to the manufacturer's instruction. The cell number was counted at seeding and controlled by equal seeding. All luciferase assays were repeated at least twice to minimize the variance caused by cell number.

About 5000 cells per well were seeded into 96-well plates. Twenty-four hours later, cells were treated with vehicle control (DMSO) or the tested compounds for 72 h. MTT assay was performed as described [17].

Whole cell lysates were prepared in 1× Laemmli sample buffer (Sigma) to extract total proteins. Equivalent amounts of total cellular protein were electrophoresed on an 8% SDS-PAGE gel and transferred onto nitrocellulose membranes (Millipore). Membranes were blocked with 5% nonfat milk in TBS containing 0.1% Tween-20 (TBST) for 1 h at room temperature, and then incubated with the corresponding primary antibodies in 5% bovine serum albumin (BSA) in TBST at 4 °C overnight. Membranes were then washed with TBST and incubated with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibody in 5% BSA in TBST for 1 h at room temperature. Immune complexes were detected by enhanced chemiluminescence (Pierce). Antibodies used in Western blotting were mouse anti-STAT3, mouse anti-Phospho-Stat3 (Tyr705), anti-JAK2, anti-Phospho-JAK2 (Tyr1007/1008) and anti-GAPDH.

Solvents were purified by standard methods. TLCs were carried out on Merck 60 F254 silica gel plates and visualized by UV irradiation. Flash column chromatography was performed on silica gel (200–300 mesh, Qingdao, China). 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded with a 400 MHz Bruker spectrometer or JEOL JNM-ECP 400 MHz spectrometers. Chemical shifts (δ) are expressed in ppm, and coupling constants (J) are expressed in Hz. Mass spectra analyses were performed on a Q-Tof Ultima Global mass spectrometer.

ce:section.ce:section-title: General procedure for the synthesis of 12a–g
ce:section.ce:para: 2-chloroacetyl chloride (1.5 mmol) was added dropwise to a mixture of amine (1 mmol) and triethylamine (3 mmol) in 20 mL dichloromethane originally at 0 °C with stirring. Then the resulting mixture was cooled to ambient temperature and stirred for 6 h. After removal of dichloromethane solvents on a rotary evaporator, water was added and extract with ethyl acetate (3 × 30 mL). The organic layer was combined and dried with sodium sulfate. The solution was evaporated to give the crude product, which was purified by Silica gel column chromatography with ethyl acetate–petroleum ether as eluent.
172.6 mg as white solid, yield 87.59%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 9.62 (s, 1H), 7.07 (d, J = 5.7 Hz, 3H), 4.26 (s, 2H), 2.12 (s, 6H). ESI [M + H]+ calcd for C10H13Cl1N1O1: 198.07, found: 198.2.

174.3 mg as yellow solid, yield 76.44%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 8.89 (s, 1H), 8.18 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 7.51 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2H), 4.42 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 2H), 4.15 (s, 2H). ESI [M + H]+ calcd for C9H10Cl1N2O3: 229.04, found: 229.1.

ce:section.ce:section-title: General procedure for the synthesis of 13a–g
ce:section.ce:para: 6-aminobenzothiazole-2-thiol (0.241 mmol) was added to a mixture of 12a–g (0.254 mmol) and potassium carbonate (0.688 mmol) in 10 mL of acetone originally at room temperature with stirring. The resulting mixture was stirred for 2 h under reflux, then cooled to ambient temperature. After removal of acetone solvents on a rotary evaporator, the solid was dissolved in dichloromethane (20 mL) and washed with water (3 × 10 mL). Then, the organic phase was dried over MgSO4 and concentrated in vacuo to give the solid product. The title compounds 13a–k were obtained respectively and could be used directly for the next step without further puriﬁcation.

ce:section.ce:section-title: General procedure for the synthesis of 14a–d
ce:section.ce:para: 4-hydrobenzoic acid (1.38 g, 10 mmol) and bromoalkane (12.5 mmol) were dissolved in ethanol (20 mL). KOH (1.23 g, 21.83 mmol) was then added and the resulting mixture was stirred under reflux for 24 h. Subsequently, KOH (1.23 g, 20.14 mmol) was added and reflux was continued for a further 1 h. After cooling to room temperature, ethanol was removed under vacuum, and the residue was resolved in water (60 mL), acidified to pH = 1 with HCl. After that, the precipitate was collected, recrystallized twice from ethanol, and finally dried under vacuum to give 14a–d (30–44%) of white solids.

ce:section.ce:section-title: General procedure for the synthesis of 15a–g
ce:section.ce:para: Thionyl chloride (10 mL) was added to carboxylic acids (0.381 mmol). The mixture was stirred and refluxed for 3 h. After cooling to room temperature, the thionyl chloride was evaporated under reduced pressure giving light yellow oil or solid. The purity of 15a–g was quite sufficient to use the product directly for the following synthesis.

ce:section.ce:section-title: General procedure for the synthesis of 16a–y
ce:section.ce:para: The acyl chloride (∼0.381 mmol) was added to a mixture of 13a–k (∼0.241 mmol) and potassium carbonate (0.508 mmol) in 10 mL of dichloromethane at room temperature with stirring. The completion of the reaction was monitored by TLC and took 4–8 h. The precipitate was collected by filtration and washed with water to yield the crude product. Each compound was puriﬁed by column chromatography on silica gel using dichloromethane/ethyl acetate as eluent or crystallized from suitable solvent to give pure target compounds 16a–y.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: This work was supported by the 11th Fudan University Graduates Innovation Project and National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 81072525).

ce:section.ce:label: Appendix A
ce:section.ce:para: Supplementary material associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ejmech.2013.01.009.
